data.name: Compound interest calculator
data.description:
Simple interest rates are, well, simple. 3% of a 1000 is 30, which is easy enough to understand. 5.6% of 1510 is 84.56, which might require a calculator but the concept remains the same. However it all gets much harder to think about when the interest gets compounded. [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compound_interest) defines compound interest as follows: "Compound interest is interest added to the principal of a deposit or loan so that the added interest also earns interest from then on. This addition of interest to the principal is called compounding." In order to calculate the total compound interest earned, you need four variables: 1. an initial value ('P' for Present Value) 2. a nominal interest rate ('i') 3. a compounding frequency ('n'), which determines how regularly the interest is compounded 4. a duration over which to calculate the interest ('t')
Once you have these four variables, there are then two steps to calculate the amount of interest earned in a given period. First, you need to calculate the future value, using the formula: F = P(1+i/n)nt The compound interest can then be calculated by finding the difference between the future value and the present value (i.e. CI = F - P). Theory is all well and good, but when you're making an investment, what you really want to know is "how much am I going to earn?" What we need is a bit of code to do the heavy lifting for us. One way to do this would be to have a function that took four variables P, i, n and t and simply calculated the interest rate. But if we wanted to re-use the compound interest rate for different initial values and durations, that would mean we would have to re-type the interest rate and compounding frequency every time we called the function! That is just wasteful. What we want is a generic compound interest function that takes a compound interest rate and returns a new function which then takes an initial value and duration and calculates the compound interest earned to two decimal places. A code example is worth a thousand words, so let's see how this should work: ```javascript // A simple example with annual compounding const annually_4_3 = { rate: '4.3%' , frequency: 'annually' } const calculateAnnually_4_3 = compoundInterest(annually_4_3) calculateAnnually_4_3(1500, 6) // returns 431.07 calculateAnnually_4_3(2000, 5) // returns 468.6 // A more complex example with compounding every two years const biennially_4_3 = { rate: '4.3%', frequency: 'biennially' } const calculateBiennially_4_3 = compoundInterest(biennially_4_3) calculateBiennially_4_3(1500, 6) // returns 421.24 calculateBiennially_4_3(1500, 7) // still returns 421.24 ``` ``` { rate: 'i%' , frequency: 'daily/weekly/monthly/quarterly/annually' } ``` The compoundInterest function should take an object in the format: ``` { rate: 'i%' , frequency: 'daily/weekly/monthly/quarterly/annually/biennially' } ``` Where rate is a string and i > 0 and frequency is one of 'daily', 'weekly', 'monthly', 'quarterly', 'annually', 'biennially'. The returned function should then take an amount (P) and a period of 't' years, where P is a number greater or equal to 0 (we're only looking at earnings on investments here) and t is an integer greater than 0. We will keep the error handling basic, so the final function should return the following string when invalid data is provided: - Invalid rate:'Invalid interest rate' - Invalid frequency: 'Invalid rate frequency' - Invalid present value: 'Invalid present value' - Invalid duration: 'Invalid duration'
